translated: Other relatives, having returned after an absence, should be greeted.

original: Vaikh / / // jyeṣṭho bhrātā pitṛvyo mātulaḥ śvaśuraś ca pitṛvat pitṛ /ṣvasā mātṛ /ṣvasā jyeṣṭha /bhharyā bhaginī jyeṣṭhā ca mātṛvatpūjitavyāḥ /
analyzed: jyeṣṭhaḥ bhrātā pitṛvyaḥ mātulaḥ śvaśuraḥ ca pitṛ vat pitṛṣvasā mātṛṣvasā jyeṣṭha bhharyā bhaginī jyeṣṭhā ca mātṛ vat pūjitavyāḥ
translated: The elder brother, the paternal uncle, the maternal uncle, the father-in-law are to be worshipped like the father. The paternal aunt, the maternal aunt, the elder wife, and the elder sister are to be worshipped like the mother.

original: Vaikh / / // sarveṣāṃ mātā śreyasī guruś ca śreyān /
analyzed: sarveṣām mātā śreyasī guruḥ ca śreyān
translated: The mother is the best among all, and the teacher is the best.

original: Vaikh / / / // paras triyaṃ yuvatim aspṛśan bhūmāvabhivādayed /
analyzed: paras triyam yuvatim a spṛśan bhūmau abhivādayet
translated: One should not touch another's wife, a young girl, or the ground while greeting.

original: Vaikh / / // vandyānāṃ vandanādāyur /jñāna /bala /ārogya /śubhāni bhavanti /
analyzed: vandyānām vandanāt āyuḥ jñāna bala ārogya śubhāni bhavanti
translated: By greeting those who are to be revered, one obtains long life, knowledge, strength, health, and auspiciousness.

original: Vaikh / / // yajña /upavīta /mekhalā /ajina /daṇḍān pareṇa dhṛtānna dhārayet /
analyzed: yajñaupavīta mekhalā ajina daṇḍān pareṇa dhṛtān na dhārayet
translated: One should not wear the sacred thread, girdle, antelope skin, or staff held by another.

original: Vaikh / / /upākṛtyaan /ālasyaḥ śuciḥ praṇava /ādyaṃ vedamadhīyānoamāvāsyāyāṃ paurṇamāsyāṃ caturdaśyoḥ pratipador aṣṭamyoś ca naadhīyīta /
analyzed: vaikh śuciḥ praṇava ādyam vedam adhīyānaḥ amāvāsyāyām paurṇamāsyām caturdaśyoḥ pratipadoḥ aṣṭamyoḥ ca na adhīyīta
translated: Having undertaken [the study of the Veda], one should not study on new moon day, full moon day, fourteenth day, first day, or eighth day, being free from laziness and pure, reciting the Praṇava and other [Vedic texts].

original: Vaikh / / // nitya /jape home caan /adhyāyo naasti /
analyzed: nitya jape home ca anadhyāyaḥ na asti
translated: There is no prohibition of study in daily recitation and oblations.

original: Vaikh / / / /mārjāra /nakula /maṇḍūka /śva /sarpa /gardabha /varāha /paśu /ādiṣv
analyzed: mārjāra nakula maṇḍūka śva sarpa gardabha varāha paśu ādiṣu
translated: With regard to cats, mongooses, frogs, dogs, snakes, donkeys, pigs, cattle, and so on,

original: antarāgateṣv ahorātraṃ sūtaka /pretakayor āśauce tāvat kālaṃ tisroaṣṭakāsu gurau
analyzed: antar āgateṣu ahar rātram sūtaka pretakayoḥ āśauce tāvat kālam tisraḥ aṣṭakāsu gurau
translated: When the days and nights have passed, the impurity (lasts) for a day and night. In the impurity of a dead person and a newborn, (the impurity lasts) for that period of time. In the three Ashtakas and on a Guru day,

original: prete ca trirātram an /adhyāyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: prete ca tri rātram anadhyāyaḥ syāt
translated: and when a person has died, there should be no study for three nights.

analyzed: tad bhāryā putrayoḥ sva śiṣyasya ca auparame manuṣyayajñe śrāddhabhojane ca eka aham anadhyāyaḥ syāt āpad ārtyoḥ aprāyatye
translated: When a Vaikhānasa, his wife, or son, or his own disciple, has died, and when a human sacrifice is performed, and when a Śrāddha feast is held, there should be no study for one day. In the case of an emergency or distress, there is no impurity.

original: Vaikh / / / / vṛkṣa /nau /yāna /śayaneṣv ārūḍhaḥ prasārita /pādo mūtra /purīṣa /reto /visarge
analyzed: vaikh vṛkṣa nau yāna śayaneṣu ārūḍhaḥ prasārita pādaḥ mūtra purīṣa retaḥ visarge
translated: When riding in a tree, boat, vehicle, or bed, with feet stretched out, when urinating, defecating, or emitting semen,

analyzed: grāme antar śave satya bhakṣya anna bhojane chardane śma ṣāna deśe sandhyā stanite bhūkampe
translated: in a village, when there is a dead body, when eating forbidden food, when vomiting, in a cremation ground, at twilight, when there is thunder, an earthquake,

analyzed: digdāhe aśani ulkā nipāte rudhira aupala pāṃsu varṣe sūrya aindu rāhu grahaṇe ca tat
translated: a conflagration, a lightning strike, a meteor shower, a rain of blood, stones, or dust, when the sun or moon is eclipsed by Rāhu, at those

analyzed: tad kāle na adhīyīta
translated: times one should not study.

analyzed: paratra eha śreyaskaraḥ vedaḥ tat adhyetavyaḥ
translated: The Veda brings about welfare in this world and the next. It should be studied.

original: Vaikh / / // ante visṛjya praṇavaṃ bravīti /
analyzed: ante visṛjya praṇavam bravīti
translated: At the end, having dismissed the Praṇava, he speaks.

original: Vaikh / / / laukika /agnau samidhau hutvā bhikṣā /annaṃmedhā /pradaṃ śuddhaṃ maunī bhuñjīta /
analyzed: vaikh laukika agnau samidhau hutvā bhikṣā annam medhā pradam śuddham maunī bhuñjīta
translated: The Vaikhānasa should offer two sticks in the worldly fire, and eat the alms-food that bestows wisdom, pure, silent.

original: Vaikh / / / / / pauṣe māghe vā msāse grāmād bahirjala /ante pūrvavad
analyzed: pauṣe māghe vā msāse grāmāt bahis jala ante pūrvavat
translated: The Vaikhānasa should, in the month of Pauṣa or Māgha, outside the village, at the edge of the water, as before,

original: vratavisarga /homaṃ hutvā svādhyāyam utsṛjya pakṣe śukle vedaṃ kṛṣṇeveda /aṅgaṃ ca
analyzed: vrata visarga homam hutvā svādhyāyam utsṛjya pakṣe śukle vedam ca
translated: having offered the fire oblation for the release of the vow, having given up the recitation of one's own Veda, in the bright fortnight the Veda, in the dark fortnight the Vedāṅgas,

original: yāvad antaṃ samadhītya guror dakṣiṇāṃ dattvā samāvartīsyāt /
analyzed: yāvat antam samadhītya guroḥ dakṣiṇām dattvā samāvartīsyāt
translated: having studied up to the end, having given the guru's fee, he should return home.

original: Vaikh / / // madhyāhne śuddhe jale mṛd /adbhiḥ pādau hastau cadhāvayitvāācamyaaṅgāni saṃśodhyaapaḥ punantv🔽iti jale nimajjed /🔽Vaikh / / // ācānto vaiṣṇavair mantrair viṣṇuṃ hiraṇya /śṛṅgamiti varuṇaṃ ca praṇamyaagha /maṛṣaṇa /sūktenaagha /maṛṣaṇaṃ kṛtvāidam
analyzed: madhyāhne śuddhe jale mṛd adbhiḥ pādau hastau ca dhāvayitvā ācamya aṅgāni saṃśodhya apaḥ punantu  iti jale nimajjet  ācāntaḥ vaiṣṇavaiḥ mantraiḥ viṣṇum hiraṇya śṛṅgam iti varuṇam ca praṇamya aghamaṛṣaṇa sūktena aghamaṛṣaṇam kṛtvā idam
translated: The Vaikhānasa, at midday, in pure water, having washed his feet and hands with clay and water, having sipped water, having purified his limbs, should immerse himself in the water, saying, May the waters purify me.🔽The Vaikhānasa, having sipped water, having bowed to Viṣṇu with the mantras sacred to Viṣṇu, Viṣṇu with golden horns, and also to Varuṇa, having performed the expiation of sins with the hymn of expiation, This,

original: āpaḥ śivāitisnāyād
analyzed: āpaḥ śivāḥ iti snāyāt
translated: should bathe with the verse, The waters are auspicious.

original: āśramiṇaś catvāraḥ snānaṃ nityam evaṃpūrva /uktena vidhinā kāmyaṃ naimittikaṃ ca kurvanti /
analyzed: āśramiṇaḥ catvāraḥ snānam nityam evaṃpūrva uktena vidhinā kāmyam naimittikam ca kurvanti
translated: The four stages of life perform the daily bath in this way, as previously stated, and also the optional and occasional baths.

original: Vaikh / / // dhauta /vastreṇaāchādya pūrvavad ācamyaprokṣyaāsīnas tiṣṭhan vā kṛta /prāṇāyāmaḥ sāvitrīṃ japtvāādityam upatiṣṭheta /🔽Vaikh / / / / dakṣiṇa /pāṇinā tīrthena brāhmeṇabhūpati /ādīn daivena nārāyaṇa /adīn🔽kūpya /adīṃś caārṣeṇa viśvāmitra /ādīn paitṛkeṇapitṛ /ādīn adbhis tarpayitvā brahmayajñaṃ
analyzed: dhauta vastreṇa āchādya pūrvavat ācamya prokṣya āsīnaḥ tiṣṭhan vā kṛta prāṇāyāmaḥ sāvitrīm japtvā ādityam upatiṣṭheta  dakṣiṇa pāṇinā tīrthena brāhmeṇa bhūpati ādīn daivena nārāyaṇa ādīn  kūpya adīn ca ārṣeṇa viśvāmitra ādīn paitṛkeṇa pitṛ ādīn adbhiḥ tarpayitvā brahmayajñam
translated: Having covered himself with a washed garment, having sipped water as before, having sprinkled (himself), sitting or standing, having performed the breath-control, having muttered the Sâvitrî, he should worship the sun.🔽Having satisfied with the water of the sacred place (called) Brâhma (the gods), with the water of the sacred place (called) Daiva (the manes), with the water of the sacred place (called) Ârṣa (the Rishis), with the water of the sacred place (called) Paitri (the fathers), with the water of the sacred place (called) Kâmya (the Kâmyas), with the water of the sacred place (called) Nândîmukha (the Nândîmukhas), with the water of the sacred place (called) Brâhma (the kings and others), with the water of the sacred place (called) Daiva (Nârâyana and others),

original: kariṣyann ity amiṣe tvāūrje tvāiti yathā /kāmaṃyajuḥ /saṃhitām ādyāṃ strīn anuvākān
analyzed: kariṣyan iti a miṣe tvā ūrje tvā iti yathākāmam yajuḥ saṃhitām ādyām strīn anuvākān
translated: with the water of the sacred place (called) Ârṣa (Viśvāmitra and others), with the water of the sacred place (called) Paitri (the fathers and others), he, who is about to perform the Brahmanical sacrifice,🔽should mutter the first hymn of the Yajurveda, the three Anuvâkas,

original: svādhyāyaṃ kurvīta /
analyzed: svādhyāyam kurvīta
translated: and should study the Sâvitrî.

original: Vaikh / / // naimittikam ṛtaṃ ca satyaṃ caity ādi /sūktānicatur vedādi /mantrān vāapy adhīyīta /
analyzed: naimittikam ṛtam ca satyam ca iti ādi sūktāni catuḥ veda ādi mantrān vā api adhīyīta
translated: He should study the hymns of the four Vedas, or the hymns beginning with Ṛta and Satya, and the hymns beginning with Aiti.

original: Vaikh / / // sarvayajñānām ādir brahmayajñaḥ /
analyzed: vaikh sarva yajñānām ādiḥ brahmayajñaḥ
translated: The Brahmanical sacrifice is the beginning of all sacrifices.

original: Vaikh / / // tasmād upanayana /prabhṛtyeva dvijaiḥ kartavyo /
analyzed: tasmāt upanayana prabhṛti eva dvijaiḥ kartavyā
translated: Therefore, it should be performed by the twice-born from the time of initiation onwards.

original: Vaikh / / // nadyāṃ tīrthe deva /khāte sarasi taṭāke vāsāmānye snānaṃ kuryāt /
analyzed: nadyām tīrthe devakhāte sarasi taṭāke vā a sāmānye snānam kuryāt
translated: He should bathe in a river, a sacred place, a tank dug by the gods, a lake, a pond, or in any ordinary water.

original: Vaikh / / // parasyaudake mṛt /piṇḍān pañcauddhṛtya snāyāt /
analyzed: parasya audake mṛd piṇḍān pañca uddhṛtya snāyāt
translated: One should bathe after taking out five lumps of clay from the water of another person.

original: Vaikh / / // kūpe tat /tīre triḥ kumbhenaabhiṣiñced /
analyzed: kūpe tad tīre tris kumbhena abhiṣiñcet
translated: In a well, one should sprinkle oneself three times with a pot on its bank.

original: Vaikh / / // ucchiṣṭo nagno vā na snāyāt
analyzed: ucchiṣṭaḥ nagnaḥ vā na snāyāt
translated: One should not bathe naked or while impure.

original: tathā na śayīta /
analyzed: tathā na śayīta
translated: Similarly, one should not sleep.

original: Vaikh / / // āturoapsu naavagāheta /
analyzed: vaikh āturaḥ apsu na avagāheta
translated: One who is sick should not enter the water.

original: Vaikh / / // āturasya snāne naimittike daśa kṛtvo dvādaśakṛtvo vā tam an /āturo jale avagāhyaācamya spṛśet
analyzed: āturasya snāne naimittike daśa kṛtvas dvādaśa kṛtvas vā tam anāturaḥ jale avagāhya ācamya spṛśet
translated: In the case of a sick person's occasional bathing, one who is not sick should enter the water ten or twelve times, sip water, and touch him.

original: tataḥ sa pūto bhavati /🔽Vaikh / / // dvi /kālaṃ homa /ante pādauprakṣālyaācamyaāsane prāṅ /mukhaḥ pratyaṅ /mukhaḥ vā sthitvā caturaśra /upalipte maṇḍale śuddhaṃ
analyzed: tatas sa pūtaḥ bhavati  dvikālam homa ante pādau prakṣālya ācamya āsane prāc mukhaḥ pratyak mukhaḥ vā sthitvā catur asra aupalipte maṇḍale śuddham
translated: Then he becomes purified.

original: pātraṃ nyaset /
analyzed: pātram nyaset
translated: Twice a day, after the fire offering, having washed the feet, sipped water, and sat on a seat facing east or west, one should place a pure vessel on a square-shaped altar.

original: Vaikh / / // tatraannaṃ prakṣipya tat pūjayati /🔽Vaikh / / // dvau pādāv ekaṃ vā bhūmau nidhāya prasannaṛtaṃ tvā satyena pariṣiñcāmi
analyzed: tatra annam prakṣipya tat pūjayati  dvau pādau ekam vā bhūmau nidhāya prasanna ṛtam tvā satyena pariṣiñcāmi
translated: In it, having put food, one worships it.

original: iti sāyaṃ pariṣiñcati
analyzed: iti sāyam pariṣiñcati
translated: Placing two feet or one on the ground, one sprinkles it in the evening with the words, With truth I sprinkle you, O pleased with truth.

original: satyaṃ tv artenapariṣiñcāmiiti prātar /
analyzed: satyam tu artena pariṣiñcāmi iti prātar
translated: With truth I sprinkle you, O pleased with truth, in the morning.

original: Vaikh / / // amṛta /upastaraṇam asiity ādhāvaṃ pītvāvidhinā prāṇa /āhutīr hutvāannam anindann aśnāti /🔽Vaikh / / / bhuktvāamṛta /apidhānam asiity apaḥpītvāācamyaācāmed /🔽Vaikh / / // eka /vāsāḥ śayānas tiṣṭhann a /snāna /japa /homīśuṣka /pāda udaṅ /mukho vā naaśnāti /
analyzed: amṛtā aupastaraṇam asi iti ādhāvam pītvā a vidhinā prāṇa āhutīḥ hutvā annam a nindan aśnāti  bhuktvā amṛta apidhānam asi iti apaḥ pītvā ācamya ācāmet  eka vāsāḥ śayānaḥ tiṣṭhan asnāna japa homī śuṣka pādaḥ udak mukhaḥ vā na aśnāti
translated: He eats food without criticizing it, after having drunk water according to the rules, and offered oblations to the vital breaths.🔽After eating, he drinks water, saying, You are the cover of nectar, performs the Ācamana rite, and then performs the Ācamana again.🔽While sleeping, standing, not bathing, not performing Japa and Homa, with dry feet, or facing the north, he does not eat.

original: Vaikh / / / // bhinna /pātreannaṃ paryuṣitaṃśayana /āsana /utsaṅga /sthaṃ vā na bhuñjīta /
analyzed: bhinna pātre annam paryuṣitam śayana āsana autsaṅga stham vā na bhuñjīta
translated: He should not eat food from a broken vessel, stale food, or food kept on a bed, seat, or lap.

original: Vaikh / / // añjalināapo na pibed /🔽Vaikh / / // ucchiṣṭa /aśucy /āśauci /patitataiḥ spṛṣṭhaṃsūtaka /pretake caannaṃ naaśnīyāt /
analyzed: añjalinā apaḥ na pibet  ucchiṣṭa aśuci āśauci patita taiḥ spṛṣṭham sūtaka pretake ca annam na aśnīyāt
translated: He should not drink water with cupped palms.🔽He should not eat food touched by an Ucchiṣṭa person, an impure person, a person in impurity, or a fallen person, or food offered to a woman in labor or a dead person.

original: Vaikh / / // tila /saktu /dadhi /lājaṃ ca rātrāv abhakṣyam /🔽Vaikh / / // annaṃ paryuṣitam ājyena dadhnā vā yuktaṃ bhojyaṃ /
analyzed: tila saktu dadhi lājam ca rātrau abhakṣyam  annam paryuṣitam ājyena dadhnā vā yuktam bhojyam
translated: Sesame seeds, flour, curd, and fried grain are not to be eaten at night.🔽Stale food mixed with ghee or curd is edible.

original: Vaikh / / // krimi /keśa /kīṭa /yutaṃ gavā /ghrātaṃ pakṣi /jagdhaṃ ca bhasma /adbhiḥ prokṣitaṃ śuddhaṃ /
analyzed: krimi keśa kīṭa yutam gavā āghrātam pakṣi jagdham ca bhasma adbhiḥ prokṣitam śuddham
translated: Food mixed with worms, hair, insects, or smelt by a cow, or eaten by birds, becomes pure when sprinkled with ashes and water.

original: Vaikh / / / śva /kākādy /upahate bahvanne tasmin puruṣa /āśamana /mātraṃ tatraevauddhṛtya
analyzed: śva kāka ādi upahate bahu anne tasmin puruṣa āśamana mātram tatra eva uddhṛtya
translated: If much food is defiled by dogs, crows, etc., then only as much as is necessary to appease the hunger of the men there should be taken out and

original: vyapohya pavamānaḥ suvarjana iti bhasma /jalaiḥ prokṣya darbha /ulkayā sparśayitvā gṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: vyapohya pavamānaḥ suvarjanaḥ iti bhasma jalaiḥ prokṣya darbha olkayā sparśayitvā gṛhṇīyāt
translated: removed, and after sprinkling it with ashes and water with the mantra Pavamānaḥ suvarjanaḥ, and touching it with the tip of a Darbha blade, it should be taken.

original: Vaikh / / // prasūteantar /daśāhe go /kṣīraṃsadāekaśapha /uṣṭra /strīṇāṃ payaś ca pala /aṇḍuka /vakala /śuna /gṛñcana /viḍjam anuktaṃreading
analyzed: prasūte antar daśa ahe go kṣīram sadā ekaśapha oṣṭra strīṇām payaḥ ca pala aṇḍu kavaka laśuna gṛñcana viḍjam an uktam reading
translated: If a cow gives birth within ten days, and also the milk of one-hoofed animals, camels, and women, as well as the flesh of birds, eggs, and vegetables, and the urine and excrement of dogs and leeks, which are not mentioned,

original: uncertain Cal p / //
analyzed: uncertain cal
translated: reading uncertain

original: matsya /māṃsaṃ ca varjanīyaṃ /
analyzed: matsya māṃsam ca varjanīyam
translated: fish and meat should be avoided.

original: Vaikh / / // yajña /śiṣṭaṃ māṃsaṃ bhakṣaṇīyam /
analyzed: vaikh yajña śiṣṭam māṃsam bhakṣaṇīyam
translated: Meat that is left over from a sacrifice may be eaten.

original: Vaikh / / // udakyā /spṛṣṭaṃ śūdra /anulomaiḥ spṛṣṭaṃ teṣāmannaṃ ca varjayet /
analyzed: udakyā spṛṣṭam śūdra anulomaiḥ spṛṣṭam teṣām annam ca varjayet
translated: One should avoid food touched by a woman in her courses, or touched by Shudras and those of mixed caste, as well as their food.

original: Vaikh / / // svadharma /anuvartināṃ śūdra /anulomānām āmaṃkṣudhitasya saṃgrāhyaṃ /
analyzed: svadharma anuvartinām śūdra anulomānām saṃgrāhyam
translated: The raw food of Shudras and those of mixed caste who follow their own duties may be accepted if one is hungry.

original: Vaikh / / // sarveṣāṃ pratiloma /antarāla /vrātyānām āmaṃpakvaṃ ca kṣudhitoapi yatnān na gṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: sarveṣām pratiloma antarāla vrātyānām āmam pakvam ca kṣudhitaḥ api yatnāt na gṛhṇīyāt
translated: Even if hungry, one should carefully not accept the raw or cooked food of all those of mixed caste who are in the reverse order or in the intermediate order, or of those who are Vrātyas.

original: Vaikh / / // taiḥ spṛṣṭi /saṃmiśraṃ para /pakvaṃ ca saṃtyajati /
analyzed: taiḥ spṛṣṭi saṃmiśram parapakvam ca saṃtyajati
translated: He should avoid food touched by them, mixed with their food, and cooked by others.

original: Vaikh / / / nityaṃ śruti /smṛti /uditaṃ karma kurvanmano /vāk /kāya /karmabhiḥ śanair dharmaṃ samācarati /
analyzed: nityam śruti smṛti uditam karma kurvat manaḥ vāc kāya karmabhiḥ śanais dharmam samācarati
translated: Always performing the duties enjoined by the Vedas and Smritis, he gradually practices righteousness with his mind, speech, and bodily actions.

original: Vaikh / / // gṛhastha /āśramī dve yajña /upavīte vaiṇavaṃdaṇḍaṃ kamaṇḍaluṃ ca dhārayet /🔽Vaikh / / // snātvā sa /bhāryo gṛhya /agnau gārhyāṇi karmāṇiśrauta /agniṣu śrautāni kuryāt /
analyzed: gṛhastha āśramī dve yajñaupavīte vaiṇavam daṇḍam kamaṇḍalum ca dhārayet  snātvā sa bhāryaḥ gṛhya agnau gārhyāṇi karmāṇi śrauta agniṣu śrautāni kuryāt
translated: The householder should wear two sacrificial threads, a bamboo staff, and a water pot.🔽Having bathed, he and his wife should perform the domestic rites in the domestic fire and the Vedic rites in the Vedic fires.

original: Vaikh / / // sāyaṃ ca homa /anteatithīn abhyāgatānprāśayitvā mitaṃ prāśya patnyā śayīta /
analyzed: sāyam ca homa ante atithīn abhyāgatān prāśayitvā mitam prāśya patnyā śayīta
translated: In the evening, after the fire offering, having fed the guests who have arrived, he should eat moderately and sleep with his wife.

original: Vaikh / / // ārdra /pādaḥ pratyaguttara /śirāś na svapity /
analyzed: ārdra pādaḥ pratyak uttara śirāḥ na svapiti
translated: He should not sleep with wet feet, facing west or north, with his head.

original: Vaikh / / // ṛtu /rātriṣu svabhāryām upagacched /
analyzed: vaikh ṛtu rātriṣu sva bhāryām upagacchet
translated: He should approach his own wife during her season.

original: Vaikh / / / ādau tri /rātramṛtumatī /gamana /sahāsana /śayanāni varjayet /
analyzed: ādau tri rātram ṛtumatī gamana sahāsana śayanāni varjayet
translated: At first, for three nights, he should avoid intercourse, sitting or sleeping together with his menstruating wife.

original: Vaikh / / // paradārān na saṃgacchet /
analyzed: vaikh paradārān na saṃgacchet
translated: He should not have intercourse with another's wife.

original: Vaikh / / // paradāra /gamanād āyuḥ śrīr brahma /varcasaṃvinaśyati /
analyzed: para dāra gamanāt āyuḥ śrīḥ brahmavarcasam vinaśyati
translated: From having intercourse with another's wife, his life, prosperity, and spiritual power are destroyed.

original: Vaikh / / // bhāryayā saha naaśnāty /
analyzed: vaikh bhāryayā saha na aśnāti
translated: He does not eat with his wife.

original: Vaikh / / // aśnantīṃ tāṃ jṛmbhamāṇāṃ nagnāṃ ca naavalokayet /
analyzed: aśnantīm tām jṛmbhamāṇām nagnām ca na avalokayet
translated: He should not look at her while she is eating, yawning, or naked.

original: Vaikh / / // asatyavādaṃ varjayaty /
analyzed: vaikh asatya vādam varjayati
translated: He avoids false speech.

original: Vaikh / / // asatyāt paraṃ pāpaṃ satyāt paro dharmaś ca naasti /
analyzed: asatyāt param pāpam satyāt paraḥ dharmaḥ ca na asti
translated: There is no greater sin than falsehood, and no greater virtue than truth.

original: Vaikh / / / sarvaprāṇi /hitoadroheṇaevajīvec
analyzed: sarva prāṇi hitaḥ adroheṇa eva jīvet
translated: He should live by non-injury alone, for the welfare of all beings.

original: śuddha /arthavān kusūla /dhānyaḥ kumbhī /dhānyoa /śvastaniko vā syāt /
analyzed: śuddha arthavān kusūladhānyaḥ kumbhīdhānyaḥ aśvastanikaḥ vā syāt
translated: He should be pure in his aims, having a granary full of grain, a jar full of grain, or a threshing floor.

original: Vaikh / / // dvijātiḥ patita /antyajātān na spṛśed /
analyzed: dvijātiḥ patita antyajātān na spṛśet
translated: A twice-born person should not touch fallen or low-caste people.

original: Vaikh / / // udayeastamaye ca sūryaṃ naīkṣeta /
analyzed: udaye astamaye ca sūryam na īkṣeta
translated: He should not look at the sun at sunrise or sunset.

original: Vaikh / / / deva /guru /vipra /ghṛta /kṣīra /dadhi /mṛt /toya /samid /darbha /agni /vanaspatīnpradakṣiṇaṃ gacchet /
analyzed: deva guru vipra ghṛta kṣīra dadhi mṛd toya samidh darbha agni vanaspatīn pradakṣiṇam gacchet
translated: He should circumambulate gods, teachers, Brahmins, ghee, milk, curd, earth, water, kindling, Darbha grass, fire, and trees.

original: Vaikh / / //snātaka /rāja /guru /śreṣṭha /rogi /bhārabhṛd /antarvatnīnāṃ deyo /Cal reads jyeṣṭha inst / of śreṣṭha / ṭr /p / /
analyzed: reads jyeṣṭha inst of śreṣṭha
translated: He should give way to a snataka, king, teacher, the most venerable, the sick, one carrying a load, or a pregnant woman.

original: Vaikh / / // vāta /arka /raśmibhiḥ panthānaḥ śudhyanti /
analyzed: vaikh vāta arka raśmibhiḥ panthānaḥ śudhyanti
translated: Roads are purified by wind and sunbeams.

original: Vaikh / / // parasyaāsana /śayanāny adattāni naupayuñjīta /
analyzed: vaikh parasya āsana śayanāni a dattāni na upayuñjīta
translated: He should not use the seat or bed of another without permission.

original: Vaikh / / // adatteṣuupayukteṣu svapuṇya /caturthāṃśo jahāti /
analyzed: adatteṣu upayukteṣu sva puṇya caturtha aṃśaḥ jahāti
translated: If he uses what has not been given, he loses a quarter of his merit.

original: Vaikh / / /anya /upayuktāni vastra /mālya /upānaṭ /chattrāṇinaeva dhārayed /🔽Vaikh / / // agnau pādaṃ na tāpayen/🔽naenaṃ mukhenadhamen
analyzed: vastra mālya aupānah chattra āṇinā eva dhārayet  agnau pādam na tāpayet  na enam mukhena dhamen
translated: He should not wear clothes, garlands, shoes, or umbrellas used by others.🔽He should not warm his feet in the fire.

original: napādena spṛśed/
analyzed: napādena spṛśet
translated: He should not fan the fire with his mouth.🔽He should not touch it with his foot.

original: adhaḥ pādato na kuryād /
analyzed: adhas pādataḥ na kuryāt
translated: He should not do it below the feet.

original: Vaikh / / / // agnāv agniṃ vā deva /ālayeagnau jale ca mūtra /purīṣa /pūya /śoṇita /retaḥ /śleṣma /ucchiṣṭa /aṅganiṣpeṣān na prakṣipet /
analyzed: agnau agnim vā deva ālaye agnau jale ca mūtra purīṣa pūya śoṇita retaḥ śleṣma aucchiṣṭa aṅga niṣpeṣān na prakṣipet
translated: He should not throw urine, feces, pus, blood, semen, phlegm, or body parts into the fire, in a temple, or in water.

original: Vaikh / / // nagnāṃ paras triyaṃ viṇ /mūtre ca na paśyed /
analyzed: nagnām paras triyam viṣ mūtre ca na paśyet
translated: He should not look at a naked woman or at urine and feces.

original: Vaikh / / // ucchiṣṭo deva /arka /candra /graha /ṛkṣa /tārā naīkṣeta /
analyzed: ucchiṣṭaḥ deva arka candra graha ṛkṣa tārāḥ na īkṣeta
translated: While impure, he should not look at the sun, moon, planets, stars, or constellations.

original: Vaikh / / // deva /guru /snātaka /dīkṣita /rāja /go /śreṣṭhānāṃchāyāṃ na ākramati /
analyzed: deva guru snātaka dīkṣita rāja go śreṣṭhānām chāyām na ākramati
translated: He should not step on the shadow of a deity, guru, snataka, initiated person, king, or a superior cow.

original: Vaikh / / // indradhanuḥ parasmai na darśayen na vadet /
analyzed: indradhanuḥ parasmai na darśayet na vadet
translated: He should not show or speak of a rainbow to another.

original: Vaikh / / // svapantaṃ naavabodhayed /
analyzed: svapantam na avabodhayet
translated: He should not wake up a sleeping person.

original: Vaikh / / // ekoadhvānaṃ na gacchet /
analyzed: ekaḥ adhvānam na gacchet
translated: One should not go alone on a journey.

original: Vaikh / / // parakṣetre carantīṃ gāṃ dhayantaṃ vatsaṃ ca navārayen/
analyzed: para kṣetre carantīm gām dhayantam vatsam ca
translated: One should not obstruct a cow grazing in another's field or a calf sucking milk.

original: na evaācakṣīta /
analyzed: na eva ācakṣīta
translated: One should not speak about it.

original: Vaikh / / // jīrṇa /mala /vāsā na syāt /
analyzed: vaikh jīrṇa mala vāsāḥ na syāt
translated: One should not be wearing old dirty clothes.

original: Vaikh / / // akṣaiḥ krīḍāṃ preta /dhūmaṃ bāla /ātāpaṃ cavarjayet /🔽Vaikh / / // keśa /roma /tuṣa /aṅgāra /kapāla /asthi /viṇ /mūtra /pūya /śoṇita /retaḥ /śleṣma /ucchiṣṭān naadhitiṣṭhet /

translated: One should avoid playing with dice, the smoke of a funeral pyre, and the heat of a child.🔽One should not step on hair, beard, chaff, charcoal, potsherds, bones, feces, urine, pus, blood, semen, phlegm, or leftovers.

original: Vaikh / / / amedhya /lipteaṅge yāvattat /lepa /gandha /manaḥśaṅkā na syāt/
analyzed: amedhya lipte aṅge yāvat tad lepa gandha manaḥ śaṅkā na syāt
translated: As long as there is a stain, smell, or suspicion of a stain on a body smeared with impure substances,

analyzed: tāvat mṛd toyaiḥ śodhayet
translated: one should purify it with clay and water.

original: Vaikh / / / patita /antyaja /mūrkhā /dhārmika /vairibhiḥsārdhaṃ na vased /
analyzed: patita antyaja mūrkha adhārmika vairibhiḥ sārdham na vaset
translated: One should not live with outcasts, low-caste people, fools, the righteous, or enemies.

original: Vaikh / / // ucchiṣṭoaśucir vā deva /go /vipra /agnīn na spṛśet /
analyzed: ucchiṣṭa u aśuciḥ vā deva go vipra agnīn na spṛśet
translated: One should not touch gods, cows, Brahmins, or fires while one is impure or has leftovers on one's body.

original: Vaikh / / // devān vedān rāja /guru /mātā /pitṛṛnvidvad /brāhmaṇān na avamanyeta/ na ninded /
analyzed: devān vedān rāja guru mātā pitṛṛn vidvas brāhmaṇān na avamanyeta na nindet
translated: One should not disrespect or criticize gods, Vedas, king, guru, mother, father, learned Brahmins.

original: Vaikh / / // avamantā nindakaś ca vinaśyati /
analyzed: avamantā nindakaḥ ca vinaśyati
translated: One who disrespects or criticizes perishes.

original: Vaikh / / // sarvabhūta /kutsāṃ tāḍanaṃ ca na kurvīta /
analyzed: sarva bhūta kutsām tāḍanam ca na kurvīta
translated: He should not revile or beat any creature.

original: Vaikh / / / guruṇā mātā /pitṛbhyāṃ tat /pitṛ /ādyair bhrātṛ /pitṛ /bhrātṛ /mātula /ācārya /ṛtvij /ādyair vivādaṃ naācaret /
analyzed: guruṇā mātā pitṛbhyām tad pitṛ ādyaiḥ bhrātṛ pitṛ bhrātṛ mātula ācārya ṛtvij ādyaiḥ vivādam na ācaret
translated: He should not dispute with his teacher, mother, father, their parents, etc., his brothers, father's brothers, maternal uncles, teachers, officiating priests, etc.

original: Vaikh / / // sarva /śuddhiṣu puruṣasyaartha /śuddhiḥstrī /śuddhir anna /śuddhiś ca śreṣṭhatamā syāt /
analyzed: sarva śuddhiṣu puruṣasya artha śuddhiḥ strī śuddhiḥ anna śuddhiḥ ca śreṣṭhatamā syāt
translated: In all purifications, the purification of a man, the purification of a woman, and the purification of food are the best.

original: Vaikh / / / / dravyeṣu ratna /sauvarṇa /rajata /mayāny adbhiḥśodhayaty/
analyzed: dravyeṣu ratna sauvarṇa rajata mayāni adbhiḥ śodhayati
translated: Among substances, those made of jewels, gold, and silver are purified by water.

original: agnau vā sparśayati /🔽Vaikh / / // tāmra /trapu /sīsa /āyasa /ādyāny amla /vāribhirdāru /danta /jātāni takṣaṇād dhāvanād vā yajña /pātrāṇi dakṣiṇa /pāṇinā mārjanātkṣālanād 🔽vā saṃśodhyāni /
analyzed: agnau vā sparśayati  tāmra trapu sīsa āyasa ādyāni amla vāribhiḥ dāru danta jātāni takṣaṇāt dhāvanāt vā yajña pātrāṇi dakṣiṇa pāṇinā mārjanāt kṣālanāt  vā saṃśodhyāni
translated: Or he should touch them to fire.🔽Copper, tin, lead, iron, etc. are purified by sour water. Wooden and ivory articles are purified by scraping or washing. Sacrificial vessels are purified by rubbing with the right hand or by washing.

original: Vaikh / / / carmamaya /saṃhatāni vastrāṇi śāka /mūla /phalānica prokṣayed/
analyzed: carma maya saṃhatāni vastrāṇi śāka mūla phalāni ca prokṣayet
translated: Leather, cloth, and bundles are purified by sprinkling.

original: alpāni kṣālayet /
analyzed: alpāni kṣālayet
translated: Small quantities are washed.

original: Vaikh / / // ghṛta /ādīni dravyāṇy utpūyaulkayā darśayet /
analyzed: ghṛta ādīni dravyāṇi utpūya olkayā darśayet
translated: Ghee and other liquids are purified by heating and then shown with a wick.

original: Vaikh / / // kauśeya /āvikāny ūṣair aṃśutaṭṭāniCal readsaṃśupaṭṭa in his tr / p //
analyzed: kauśeya āvikāni ūṣaiḥ
translated: (The purification of) silk, wool, and linen (is effected) by means of cow's urine, (that of) cotton by means of the decoction of the Kusha grass, (that of) silk by means of the decoction of the Shirisha tree.

original: śrīphalaiḥ śaṅkha /śukti /gośṛṅgāṇi sarṣapaiḥ sa /vāribhirmṛtmayāni punar dāhena gṛhaṃ
analyzed: śrīphalaiḥ śaṅkha śukti gośṛṅgāṇi sarṣapaiḥ sa vāribhiḥ mṛd mayāni punar dāhena gṛham
translated: (The purification of) conch-shells, mother-of-pearl, and cow's horns (is effected) by means of mustard seeds and water, (that of) a house by means of a second burning.

original: mārjana /upalepana /apsekair bhūmiṃ khananādanyamṛt /pūraṇa /govāsaka /ādyair mārjana /ādyaiś ca śodhayed /🔽Vaikh / / // gotṛpti /karaṃ bhū /gataṃ toyaṃ doṣa /vihīnaṃ su /pūtaṃ /🔽Vaikh / / // vāk /śastaṃ vāri /nirṇiktam adṛṣṭaṃ /
analyzed: mārjana aupalepana ap sekaiḥ bhūmim khanana adanya mṛd pūraṇa go vāsaka ādyaiḥ mārjana ādyaiḥ ca śodhayet  go tṛpti karam bhū gatam toyam doṣa vihīnam su pūtam  vāc śastam vāri nirṇiktam adṛṣṭam
translated: (The purification of) the ground (is effected) by means of sweeping, besmearing, sprinkling, and digging, (that of) earth by filling (the place) with earth and besmearing it with cowdung, &c., and by sweeping, &c.🔽(The purification of) water which has reached the ground and which causes satisfaction to cows (is effected) by removing the faults (of it) and by straining it well.🔽(The purification of) water (is effected) by straining it with a cloth, by boiling it, and by looking at it.

original: Vaikh / / / yoṣid /āsyaṃ kāru /hastaḥ prasārita /paṇyaṃ casarvadā śuddhaṃ /
analyzed: yoṣit āsyam kāru hastaḥ prasārita paṇyam ca sarvadā śuddham
translated: (The purification of) the mouth of a woman, the hand of a goldsmith, and merchandise which is spread out (for sale) is always pure.

original: Vaikh / / // śakuni /ucchiṣṭaṃ phalam anindyaṃ /
analyzed: vaikh śakuni ucchiṣṭam phalam anindyam
translated: (The purification of) fruit which has been pecked at by birds is not reprehensible.

original: Vaikh / / // maśaka /makṣikā /nilīnaṃ tad /vipruṣaś ca na dūṣyāṇi /
analyzed: maśaka makṣikā nilīnam tad vipruṣaḥ ca na dūṣyāṇi
translated: (The purification of) water which has been touched by mosquitoes and flies and the drops (falling from their wings) is not defiled.

original: Vaikh / / // vāyu /agni /sūryaraśmibhiḥ spṛṣṭaṃ ca medhyam /
analyzed: vaikh vāyu agni sūrya raśmibhiḥ spṛṣṭam ca medhyam
translated: (The purification of) water which has been touched by the wind, fire, and the sun's rays is pure.

original: Vaikh / / // āture bāle pacana /ālaye ca śaucaṃ navicāraṇīyaṃ yathā /śakti syād /
analyzed: āture bāle pacana ālaye ca śaucam na vicāraṇīyam yathāśakti syāt
translated: (The purification of) a sick person, a child, and a place where food is cooked (is effected) without any consideration (of the number of days required for it); it should be done according to one's ability.

original: Vaikh / / // viṇ /mūtrābhyāṃ bahu /āpo na dūṣyāḥ /
analyzed: viṣ mūtrābhyām bahu apaḥ na dūṣyāḥ
translated: The excrement and urine of many animals do not defile the water.

original: Vaikh / / / parasyaācāmatas toya /bindubhir bhūmaunipatyaudgataiḥ pāda /spṛṣtair ācāmayan naaśuciḥ syāt /
analyzed: parasya ācāmataḥ toya bindubhiḥ bhūmau nipatya udgataiḥ pāda spṛṣtaiḥ ācāmayan na aśuciḥ syāt
translated: When water drops fall on the ground from one who is sipping water, and rise up and touch the feet, one who sips with them is not impure.

original: Vaikh / / // vānaprastho nitya /svādhyāyī kuśa /idhma /ādīnagni /arthaṃ śāka /mūla /phalāny aśana /arthaṃ ca śucau jātāny āhared /
analyzed: vaikh vānaprasthaḥ nitya svādhyāyī kuśa aidhma ādīn agni artham śāka mūla phalāni aśana artham ca śucau jātāni āharet
translated: A forest hermit, always studying the Veda, should collect kusha grass, fuel, etc. for the fire, and vegetables, roots, and fruits for food, which have grown in a pure place.

original: Vaikh / / // anya /adhīnam anya /utsṛṣṭam aśucau jātaṃ gorasaṃca varjayet /
analyzed: anya adhīnam anya autsṛṣṭam aśucau jātam gorasam ca varjayet
translated: He should avoid grains, wealth, and accumulations, which are dependent on others and abandoned by others, and milk products that have grown in an impure place.

original: Vaikh / / // dhānya /dhana /saṃcayaṃ na kurvīta /
analyzed: vaikh dhānya dhana saṃcayam na kurvīta
translated: He should not make a hoard of grains and wealth.

original: Vaikh / / // vastraṃ naāchādayet /
analyzed: vaikh vastram na āchādayet
translated: He should not cover himself with a cloth.

original: Vaikh / / // madhu /ukte toyaṃ māṃsa /ukte paiṣṭikaṃ gṛhṇāti /
analyzed: vaikh madhu ukte toyam māṃsa okte paiṣṭikam gṛhṇāti
translated: If honey is mentioned, he accepts water; if meat is mentioned, he accepts what is made of flour.

original: Vaikh / / / / sarvabhūteṣu dayāluḥ samaḥ kṣāntaḥ śucirnir /asūyakaḥ sukhe
analyzed: sarva bhūteṣu dayāluḥ samaḥ kṣāntaḥ śuciḥ nirasūyakaḥ sukhe
translated: He is compassionate towards all beings, impartial, patient, pure, free from malice, not desirous of happiness,

original: niḥ /spṛho maṅgalya /vāṇi /īrṣyā /kārpaṇya /varjī matsya /ādīn daṃśakānsīra /kṛṣṭa /jātāni
analyzed: niḥspṛhaḥ maṅgalya vāṇi īrṣyā kārpaṇya varjī matsya ādīn daṃśakān sīra kṛṣṭa jātāni
translated: a speaker of auspicious things, free from envy and stinginess, and avoids fish and other biting insects, and those that grow in plowed fields,

original: kanda /mūla /phala /śāka /ādīni ca tyajanjaṭā /śmaśru /roma /nakhāni dhārayaṃs trikāla /snāyī
analyzed: kanda mūla phala śāka ādīni ca tyajan jaṭā śmaśru roma nakhāni dhārayan tri kāla snāyī
translated: Abandoning roots, fruits, vegetables, etc., wearing matted hair, beard, body hair, and nails, bathing three times a day,

original: dharā / āśayo vanyair eva caru /puroḍaśān nirvapet /🔽Vaikh / / // palāṇḍu /ādīn niryāsaṃ śvetavṛntākaṃ suniṣaṇṇakaṃ śleṣmātakaṃ vrajakaliṃ citrakaṃ śigruṃ bhūs tṛṇaṃ kovidāraṃ mūlakaṃ
analyzed: dharāḥ āśayaḥ vanyaiḥ eva caru puroḍaśān nirvapet  palāṇḍu ādīn niryāsam śvetavṛntākam suniṣaṇṇakam śleṣmātakam vrajakalim citrakam śigrum bhūḥ tṛṇam kovidāram mūlakam
translated: with the earth as his abode, he should offer oblations of wild rice and cakes with wild grains.

original: Vaikh / / // muneḥ sarvaṃ māṃsaṃ gomāṃsa /tulyaṃ dhānya /āmlaṃ surā /samaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: muneḥ sarvam māṃsam go māṃsa tulyam dhānya āmlam surā samam bhavati
translated: For the Muni, all meat is equal to beef, and grain-sour is equal to liquor.

original: Vaikh / / // pūrvasaṃcita /āśanaṃ pūrvāṇi vasanāny āśvayujemāsi tyajati /
analyzed: vaikh pūrva saṃcita aśanam pūrvāṇi vasanāni āśvayuja imāsi tyajati
translated: In the month of Ashvayuja, he abandons previously accumulated food and previous garments.

original: Vaikh / / // veda /vedāntena dhyāna /yogī tapaḥ samācarati /
analyzed: vaikh veda vedāntena dhyāna yogī tapaḥ samācarati
translated: The meditator, through the Vedas and Vedanta, practices austerities.

original: Vaikh / / / / / a /patnīkoan /agnir a /dāroa /niketanovṛkṣamūle vasan
analyzed: a patnīkaḥ anagniḥ a dāraḥ a niketanaḥ vṛkṣa mūle vasan
translated: Without a wife, without a fire, without a wife, without a dwelling, living at the foot of a tree,

original: vanastha /āśrameṣu gṛhasthānāṃ gṛheṣu vā bhikṣāṃbhikṣitvāambu /pārśve śuddhe parṇe
analyzed: vanastha āśrameṣu gṛhasthānām gṛheṣu vā bhikṣām bhikṣitvā ambu pārśve śuddhe parṇe
translated: in the hermitages of forest-dwellers, or in the houses of householders, having begged for alms, on a pure leaf near water,

original: prāṇayātrā /mātram annaṃ bhikṣuvad aśnāti /
analyzed: prāṇa yātrā mātram annam bhikṣu vat aśnāti
translated: he eats food just for the sustenance of life, like a mendicant.

original: Vaikh / / // śarīraṃ śoṣayann uttaram uttaraṃ tīvraṃ tapaḥ kuryāt /
analyzed: śarīram śoṣayan uttaram uttaram tīvram tapaḥ kuryāt
translated: The naked ascetic should practice increasingly severe austerities, drying up his body.

original: Vaikh / / // bhikṣuḥ snātvā nityaṃ praṇavenaātmānaṃ tarpayet /
analyzed: bhikṣuḥ snātvā nityam praṇavena ātmānam tarpayet
translated: The mendicant, having bathed, should daily satisfy his soul with the Pranava.

original: Vaikh / / // tenaeva namaskuryāt /
analyzed: vaikh tena eva namaskuryāt
translated: With that very [Pranava] he should offer salutations.

original: Vaikh / / // ṣaḍ avarān prāṇāyāmān kṛtvā śata /avarāṃsāvitrīṃ japtvā sandhyām upāsīta /
analyzed: ṣaṭ avarān prāṇāyāmān kṛtvā śata avarān sāvitrīm japtvā sandhyām upāsīta
translated: Having performed the six lower breath-control exercises and having muttered the Savitri [hymn] one hundred times or more, he should perform the Sandhya worship.

original: Vaikh / / // ap /pavitreṇautpūtābhir adbhir ācāmet /
analyzed: appavitreṇa autpūtābhiḥ adbhiḥ ācāmet
translated: He should sip water with water purified by the Ap-pavitra.

original: Vaikh / / // kāṣāya /dhāraṇaṃ sarva /tyāgaṃ maithuna /varjanamastainya /ādīn apyācaret /
analyzed: kāṣāya dhāraṇam sarva tyāgam maithuna varjanam a stainya ādīn api ācaret
translated: He should wear ochre robes, renounce everything, abstain from sexual intercourse, and also practice non-stealing and so on.

original: Vaikh / / / / a /sahāyoan /agnir a /niketano niḥ /saṃśayīsaṃmāna /avamāna /samo
analyzed: a sahāyaḥ anagniḥ a niketanaḥ niḥsaṃśayī saṃmāna avamāna samaḥ
translated: Without a companion, without a sacred fire, without a fixed abode, free from doubt, equal in honor and dishonor,

original: vivāda /krodha /lobha /moha /anṛta /varjī grāmād bahir vivikte maṭhedeva /ālaye vṛkṣamūle vā nivaset /
analyzed: vivāda krodha lobha moha anṛta varjī grāmāt bahis vivikte maṭhe deva ālaye vṛkṣa mūle vā nivaset
translated: free from disputes, anger, greed, delusion, and falsehood, he should dwell outside the village in a secluded hermitage, temple, or at the foot of a tree.

original: Vaikh / / // cāturmāsād anyatraekāhād ūrdhvam ekasmin deśe na vased /
analyzed: vaikh cāturmāsāt anyatra ekāhāt ūrdhvam ekasmin deśe na vaset
translated: Except during the four months, he should not dwell in one place for more than one day.

original: Vaikh / / // varṣāḥ śarac cāturmāsyam ekatraeva vaset /
analyzed: vaikh varṣāḥ śarad cāturmāsyam ekatra eva vaset
translated: During the rainy season and the four months of autumn, he may dwell in one place.

original: Vaikh / / / / tridaṇḍe kāṣāya /ap /pavitra /ādīn yojayitvā kaṇṭhe vāma /hastena
analyzed: tri daṇḍe kāṣāya appavitra ādīn yojayitvā kaṇṭhe vāma hastena
translated: The mendicant, having applied the three staffs, the ochre robes, the sacred thread, etc., holding them on his neck with his left hand,

original: dhārayan dakṣiṇena bhikṣā /pātraṃ gṛhītvāekakāle viprāṇāṃśuddhānāṃ gṛheṣu vaiśvadeva /ante bhikṣāṃ caret /🔽Vaikh / / // bhūmau vīkṣya jantūn pariharan pādaṃ nyased /
analyzed: dhārayan dakṣiṇena bhikṣā pātram gṛhītvā eka kāle viprāṇām śuddhānām gṛheṣu vaiśvadeva ante bhikṣām caret  bhūmau vīkṣya jantūn pariharan pādam nyaset
translated: taking the alms bowl in his right hand, at one time in the houses of pure Brahmins, after the Vishvadeva rite, he should go for alms.🔽The mendicant, having seen creatures on the ground, avoiding them, should place his foot.

original: Vaikh / / // adho /mukhas tiṣṭhan bhikṣām ālipsate /
analyzed: adhomukhaḥ tiṣṭhan bhikṣām ālipsate
translated: The mendicant, standing with his face down, should seek alms.

original: Vaikh / / // godohana /kāla /mātraṃ tad /ardhaṃ vā sthitvā vrajed /
analyzed: godohana kāla mātram tad ardham vā sthitvā vrajet
translated: The mendicant, having stood for the time of milking a cow or half of that, should go.

original: Vaikh / / // alābheapyavamāneapyaviṣādī labdhesaṃmāneapy a /saṃtoṣī syāt /
analyzed: alābhe api avamāne api aviṣādī labdhe saṃmāne api a saṃtoṣī syāt
translated: The mendicant, even in the absence of alms or disrespect, should be without dejection, and even in the acquisition of honor, without satisfaction.

original: Vaikh / / // drutaṃ vilambitaṃ vā na gacchet /
analyzed: drutam vilambitam vā na gacchet
translated: The mendicant should not go either quickly or slowly.

original: Vaikh / / // bhikṣā /kālād anyatra para /veśma na gantavyaṃ /
analyzed: bhikṣā kālāt anyatra para veśma na gantavyam
translated: The mendicant should not go to another's house except at the time of begging for alms.

original: Vaikh / / // bhikṣituṃ krośād ūrdhvaṃ na gacchet /
analyzed: vaikh bhikṣitum krośāt ūrdhvam na gacchet
translated: The mendicant should not go beyond a krosha to beg for alms.

original: Vaikh / / / / / bhikṣāṃ caritvā toya /pārśveprakṣālita /pāṇi /pāda ācamyaud
analyzed: bhikṣām caritvā toya pārśve prakṣālita pāṇi pādaḥ
translated: The mendicant, having gone for alms, having washed his hands and feet near water, having sipped water,

original: u tyam ityādityāyaato devā iti viṣṇave brahma jajñām iti brahmaṇe ca bhikṣā /agraṃ
analyzed: u tyam iti ādityāya atas devāḥ iti viṣṇave brahma iti brahmaṇe ca bhikṣā agram
translated: The verse Utyam is for the Sun, Atah is for Vishnu, and Brahma jajnam is for Brahma. The first portion of the verse is for the Sun.

original: dattvā sarvabhūtebhyaiti baliṃ prakṣipet /
analyzed: dattvā sarva bhūtebhyaḥ eti balim prakṣipet
translated: Then, having given the first portion to the sun, to Vishnu with O gods, to Brahma with Brahma was born, and to all beings, he should throw the oblation.

original: Vaikh / / // pāṇināagnihotra /vidhānenaātmayajñaṃ saṃkalpya prāṇayātrā /mātram aṣṭau grāsān vāaśnīyāt
analyzed: pāṇinā agnihotra vidhānena ātma yajñam saṃkalpya prāṇayātrā mātram aṣṭau grāsān vā aśnīyāt
translated: Having performed the self-sacrifice according to the rules of the Agnihotra with the hand, he should eat just enough for subsistence or eight morsels.

original: kāmaṃ naaśnāti /
analyzed: kāmam na aśnāti
translated: He may or may not eat according to desire.

original: Vaikh / / // vastra /pūtaṃ jalaṃ pītvāācamyaācāmati /
analyzed: vastra pūtam jalam pītvā ācamya ācāmati
translated: Having drunk water purified by a cloth and sipped water, he should sip water.

original: Vaikh / / // nindā /krośau na kurvīta /
analyzed: nindā krośau na kurvīta
translated: He should not utter censure or cries.

original: Vaikh / / // bandhūñ jñātīṃs tyajed /
analyzed: bandhūm jñātīn tyajet
translated: He should abandon relatives and kinsmen.

original: Vaikh / / // vaṃśa /cāritraṃ tapaḥ śrutaṃ na vadet /🔽Vaikh / / / saṅgaṃ tyaktvā niyama /yamī priyaṃ satyaṃ vadansarvabhūtasyaavirodhī samaḥ sadāadhyātma /rato dhyāna /yogī nārāyaṇaṃ paraṃ
analyzed: vaṃśa cāritram tapaḥ śrutam na vadet  saṅgam tyaktvā niyama yamī priyam satyam vadan sarva bhūtasya avirodhī samaḥ sadā adhyātma rataḥ dhyāna yogī nārāyaṇam param
translated: He should not speak of his family, character, austerities, or learning.

original: brahmapaśyan dhāraṇāṃ dhārayed /
analyzed: brahma paśyan dhāraṇām dhārayet
translated: Having abandoned attachment, observing rules and self-control, speaking truth and pleasing, not opposing any being, always equal, devoted to spiritual matters, a yogi of meditation, seeing Narayana as the supreme Brahman, he should practice concentration.

original: Vaikh / / // akṣaraṃ brahmaāpnoti /
analyzed: vaikh akṣaram brahma āpnoti
translated: He attains the imperishable Brahman.

original: Vaikh / / // nārāyaṇaḥ paraṃ brahmaiti śrutiḥ /
analyzed: nārāyaṇaḥ param brahma eti śrutiḥ
translated: The scripture says Narayana is the supreme Brahman.

original: Vaikh / / / / saṃnyāsinoan /āhitāgner dehaṃ mṛtaṃ putroanyovā tṛṇair
analyzed: saṃnyāsinaḥ anāhitāgneḥ deham mṛtam putraḥ anyaḥ vā tṛṇaiḥ
translated: The son or another of the dead body of a renunciant or a householder with the sacred fires, having separated it with pure grass,

original: antarīkṛtya śuddhair brāhmaṇair yantreṇa vā saṃnidhāya samudra /gāmyāṃnadyāṃ tīre
analyzed: antarīkṛtya śuddhaiḥ brāhmaṇaiḥ yantreṇa vā saṃnidhāya samudra gāmyām nadyām tīre
translated: or having placed it on a machine with pure Brahmins, digs a pit on the bank of a river flowing to the ocean,

original: vā saikate deśe sṛgāla /ādibhir aspṛśyaṃ yathā tathāavaṭaṃ khanati /
analyzed: vā saikate deśe sṛgāla ādibhiḥ aspṛśyam yathā tathā avaṭam khanati
translated: or on a sandy place, so that it is not touched by jackals etc.

original: Vaikh / / / / / gāyatryā snāpayitvā tathātatraāsayitvā śāyayitvā vā
analyzed: gāyatryā snāpayitvā tathā tatra āsayitvā śāyayitvā vā
translated: Having bathed with the Gayatri, and having placed it there in the same way, or having laid it down,

original: dakṣiṇe haste vaiṣṇavair mantrais tri /daṇḍaṃ saṃnyasya savye yad asya pārerajasa
analyzed: dakṣiṇe haste vaiṣṇavaiḥ mantraiḥ tridaṇḍam saṃnyasya savye yat asya pārerajasa
translated: he should deposit the three staffs in the right hand with the Vishnu mantras, the sling with the mantra yad asya pare rajas

original: iti śikyam ap /pavitram udare sāvitryā bhikṣā /pātraṃ guhyapradeśe bhūmir bhūmimiti
analyzed: iti śikyam appavitram udare sāvitryāḥ bhikṣāpātram guhya pradeśe bhūmiḥ bhūmim iti
translated: on the chest, the water strainer with the Savitri mantra, the alms bowl in the genital region with the mantra bhumih bhuvar

original: kāṣāyaṃ mṛd /grahaṇīṃ kamaṇḍaluṃ ca saṃnyasya pidadhyāt /
analyzed: kāṣāyam mṛd grahaṇīm kamaṇḍalum ca saṃnyasya pidadhyāt
translated: and the ochre robe and clay pot, having deposited the water pot, he should cover it.

original: Vaikh / / / tasmin sṛgāla /ādibhiḥ spṛṣṭe tat /kartā pāpīyānbhavati /
analyzed: tasmin sṛgāla ādibhiḥ spṛṣṭe tad kartā pāpīyān bhavati
translated: If it is touched by jackals etc., the doer of that becomes a sinner.

original: Vaikh / / // āhitāgner agnīn ātmany āropya saṃnyasino mṛtaṃdehaṃ gāyatryā snāpayitvā pūrvavad vāhayitvā śuddhe deśe nidhāya laukika /agnau
analyzed: āhitāgneḥ agnīn ātmani āropya mṛtam deham gāyatryā snāpayitvā pūrvavat vāhayitvā śuddhe deśe nidhāya laukika agnau
translated: The funeral rites of one who has renounced after having consigned the sacred fires into himself should be performed as follows: Having consigned the sacred fires into himself, having bathed the dead body of the renouncer with the Gāyatrī mantra, having carried it as before, having placed it in a pure place, in the worldly fire,

original: tadagnim upāvaroha
analyzed: tat agnim upāvaroha
translated: having consigned that fire into himself with the formula I enter into you,

original: ity avaropya pavitraṃ taiti ghṛta /kṣīram āsye prakṣipya pūrvavattri /daṇḍa /ādīn vinyasya brahmamedhena pitṛmedhena vāāhitāgni /mantrais tad /agnibhir
analyzed: iti avaropya pavitram te iti ghṛta kṣīram āsye prakṣipya pūrvavat tridaṇḍa ādīn vinyasya brahmamedhena pitṛ medhena vā āhitāgni mantraiḥ tad agnibhiḥ
translated: having thrown the sacred thread, ghee and milk into his mouth, having placed the three staffs etc. as before, with the Brahmayajña or Pitriyajña mantras, with those fires,

original: Vaikh / / / tayor āśauca /udaka /bali /piṇḍa /dāna /ekoddiṣṭa /ādīnnaeva kuryāt /
analyzed: tayoḥ āśauca audaka bali piṇḍa dāna ekoddiṣṭa ādīn na eva kuryāt
translated: he should not perform the impurity, water offering, bali, funeral cakes, ekoddista and so on for them.

original: Vaikh / / // nārāyaṇa /baliṃ karoti /
analyzed: vaikh nārāyaṇa balim karoti
translated: He performs the Narayana bali.

original: Vaikh / / // tad /vahanaṃ khanitvā pidhānaṃ dahanaṃnārāyaṇa /baliṃ vā yaḥ kuryāt/
analyzed: tat vahanam khanitvā pidhānam dahanam nārāyaṇa balim vā yaḥ kuryāt
translated: He who performs the carrying, digging, covering, burning or Narayana bali of that,

original: soaśvamedha /phalaṃ samāpnuyāt /
analyzed: saḥ aśvamedha phalam samāpnuyāt
translated: he would obtain the fruit of a horse sacrifice.

original: Vaikh / / / nārāyaṇa /baliṃ nārāyaṇād evasarvārtha /siddhir iti brahmaṇa /ādyair
analyzed: nārāyaṇabalim nārāyaṇāt eva sarva artha siddhiḥ iti brahmaṇa ādyaiḥ
translated: From Narayana alone, the accomplishment of all objectives, thus by Brahma and others,

original: narair hatasyaātma /ghātinorajju /śastra /udaka /aśani /daṃṣṭri /paśu /sarpa /ādibhiḥ sarvapāpa /mṛtasyaadāhyānām
analyzed: naraiḥ hatasya ātmaghātinaḥ rajju śastra audaka aśani daṃṣṭri paśu sarpa ādibhiḥ sarva pāpa mṛtasya adāhyānām
translated: For one who has died by a man, by a self-killer, by a rope, by a weapon, by water, by lightning, by a fanged animal, by an animal, by a snake, etc., for one who has died of all sins, for one who is not to be cremated,

original: anyeṣāṃ bhikṣoś caekādaśa /dinād ūrdhvaṃ mahāpātakināṃ pañcānāṃ dvādaśa /saṃvatsarād
analyzed: anyeṣām bhikṣoḥ ca ekādaśa dināt ūrdhvam mahāpātakinām pañcānām dvādaśa saṃvatsarāt
translated: and for others, for a monk, after eleven days, for the five great sinners, after twelve years,

original: ūrdhvaṃsapiṇḍīkaraṇa /sthāne mṛtaka /artham aparapakṣe dvādaśyāṃ śravaṇe vā
analyzed: ūrdhva sapiṇḍīkaraṇa sthāne mṛtaka artham aparapakṣe dvādaśyām śravaṇe vā
translated: after that, in the place of Pindīkaraṇa, for the sake of the dead, in the dark fortnight on the twelfth day or in Śravaṇa,

original: karoti /
analyzed: karoti
translated: he performs.

original: Vaikh / / // pūrveahani dvādaśa brāhmaṇān nimantrayed /🔽Vaikh / / // apareahani viṣṇor ālaya /pārśve nadī /tīregṛhe vāagni /āyatanaṃ kṛtvāāghāraṃ juhuyād /
analyzed: pūrveahani dvādaśa brāhmaṇān nimantrayet  apare ahani viṣṇoḥ ālaya pārśve nadī tīre gṛhe vā agni āyatanam kṛtvā āghāram juhuyāt
translated: On the previous day, a Vaikhānasa should invite twelve Brahmins.🔽On the next day, having made a fire altar on the bank of a river or in a house near the abode of Viṣṇu, he should offer an Āghāra oblation.

original: Vaikh / / / / / agniṃ paristīryaagner vāyavyāṃ viṣṭaredarbheṣu tad /rūpaṃ
analyzed: agnim paristīrya agneḥ vāyavyām viṣṭaret arbheṣu tat rūpam
translated: Having surrounded the fire, he should place the form of Viṣṇu or a golden image on a seat in the northwest of the fire on Darbha grass,

original: suvarṇaṃ vā saṃsthāpya puruṣaṃ dhyāyann oṃ bhūḥ puruṣam ity ādyaiḥprāṅ /mukhaṃ devaṃ
analyzed: suvarṇam vā saṃsthāpya puruṣam dhyāyan om bhūḥ puruṣam iti ādyaiḥ prāc mukham devam
translated: meditating on the Puruṣa, with the words Om Bhūḥ Puruṣa etc., facing east,

original: nārāyaṇam āvāhyaāsana /pādya /ācamanāni dadyāt /
analyzed: nārāyaṇam āvāhya āsana pādya ācamanāni dadyāt
translated: having invoked the god Nārāyaṇa, he should offer him a seat, water for washing the feet, and water for sipping.

original: Vaikh / / // puruṣasūktena snāpayitvā
analyzed: vaikh puruṣasūktena snāpayitvā
translated: Having bathed with the Puruṣa Sūkta,

original: nārāyaṇāyavidmaha
analyzed: nārāyaṇāya vidmaha
translated: We meditate on Narayana,

original: ity aṣṭākṣara /mantreṇa vā vastra /uttarīya /ābharaṇa /pādya /ācamana /puṣpa /gandha /dhūpa /dīpa /akṣata /ācamanair arcayati /
analyzed: iti aṣṭa akṣara mantreṇa vā vastra auttarīya ābharaṇa pādya ācamana puṣpa gandha dhūpa dīpa akṣata ācamanaiḥ arcayati
translated: Thus, with the eight-syllable mantra, he worships with cloth, upper garment, ornaments, water for washing the feet and face, flowers, incense, perfume, lamps, unbroken rice, and water for sipping.

original: Vaikh / / // keśava /ādyair dvādaśa /nāmabhir adbhis tarpayet /
analyzed: keśava ādyaiḥ dvādaśa nāmabhiḥ adbhiḥ tarpayet
translated: With the twelve names beginning with Keśava, he should offer water libations.

original: Vaikh / / // pariṣicya sahasraśīrṣa /ādyair viṣṇor nuka /ādyairdvādaśa /nāmabhiś caājyaṃ caruṃ juhuyāt /
analyzed: pariṣicya sahasra śīrṣa ādyaiḥ viṣṇoḥ nu ka ādyaiḥ dvādaśa nāmabhiḥ ca ājyam carum juhuyāt
translated: Having sprinkled with the thousand-headed etc. and the twelve names beginning with Viṣṇu's nose, he should offer ghee and rice cooked in milk to the fire.

original: Vaikh / / // guḍa /ājya /phala /yuktaṃ pāyasaṃ havirviṣṇu /gāyatryā deva /īśāya nivedya pādya /ācamana /mukha /vāsaṃ dadyāt /
analyzed: guḍa ājya phala yuktam pāyasam haviḥ viṣṇugāyatryā deva īśāya nivedya pādya ācamana mukha vāsam dadyāt
translated: Having offered as oblation the rice cooked in milk mixed with jaggery, ghee, and fruits to the Lord of gods with the Viṣṇu Gāyatrī, he should give water for washing the feet, water for sipping, and mouth-perfume.

original: Vaikh / / / agner dakṣiṇe darbheṣuūtara /agreṣu dakṣiṇādyarcayitvā/
analyzed: agneḥ dakṣiṇe dakṣiṇa ādi arcayitvā
translated: On the kuśa grass with tips facing north, to the south of the fire, having worshipped from the south onwards,

original: nārāyaṇāya sahasraśīrṣāya sahasrākṣāya sahasrapādāyaparamapuruṣāya paramātmane paraṃjyotiṣe
analyzed: nārāyaṇāya sahasra śīrṣāya sahasra akṣāya sahasra pādāya paramapuruṣāya paramātmane paraṃjyotiṣe
translated: to Nārāyaṇa, the thousand-headed, the thousand-eyed, the thousand-footed, the supreme person, the supreme self, the supreme light,

original: parabrahmaṇe avyaktāya sarvakāraṇāya yajña /īśvarāyayajñātmane viśvebhyo devebhyaḥ
analyzed: para brahmaṇe avyaktāya sarva kāraṇāya yajñaīśvarāya yajñātmane viśvebhyaḥ devebhyaḥ
translated: to the supreme Brahman, the unmanifest, the cause of all, the Lord of sacrifice, the essence of sacrifice, to all the gods,

original: sarvābhyo devatābhyaḥ sādhyebhyaity antaiḥ pāyasaṃ baliṃdattvā
analyzed: sarvābhyaḥ devatābhyaḥ sādhyebhyaḥ eti antaiḥ pāyasam balim dattvā
translated: to all the deities, to the Sādhyas, having offered the rice cooked in milk as oblation with the final (mantras),

original: ājyam ebhirjuhoti /
analyzed: ājyam ebhiḥ juhoti
translated: He offers clarified butter with these.

original: Vaikh / / / brāhmaṇān pādau prakṣālya navānivastra /uttarīya /ābharaṇāni🔽dattvā puṣpa /ādyaiḥ pūjayitvā dvādaśa /mūrtiṃ dhyāyann upadaṃśa /ghṛta /guḍa /dadhi /phala /yuktaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇān pādau prakṣālya  dattvā puṣpa ādyaiḥ pūjayitvā dvādaśamūrtim dhyāyan upadaṃśa ghṛta guḍa dadhi phala yuktam
translated: Having washed the feet of the Brahmins with this, and having given them new garments, upper garments, and ornaments,🔽having worshipped them with flowers etc., meditating on the twelve forms, having fed them white food along with side dishes, ghee, jaggery, curd, and fruits,

original: śvetam annaṃ bhojayitvāyathā /śakti suvarṇaṃ dakṣiṇāṃ dadāti /
analyzed: śvetam annam bhojayitvā ayathāśakti suvarṇam dakṣiṇām dadāti
translated: he gives gold as dakshina according to his ability.

original: Vaikh / / / // sahasraśīrṣa /ādyaiḥ stutvādvādaśa /nāmabhiḥ praṇamed
analyzed: sahasra śīrṣa ādyaiḥ stutvā dvādaśa nāmabhiḥ praṇamet
translated: Having praised with the thousand-headed hymn etc., he should bow with the twelve names.

original: anta /homaṃ juhoty /
analyzed: anta homam juhoti
translated: He offers the final oblation.

original: Vaikh / / // abhīṣṭāṃ parāṃ gatiṃ sa gatvā viṣṇor lokemahīyate /
analyzed: abhīṣṭām parām gatim sa gatvā viṣṇoḥ loke mahīyate
translated: He, having attained the highest goal desired, is honored in Vishnu's world.

original: Vaikh / / // cāturvarṇya /saṃkareṇautpannānām anuloma /pratiloma /antarāla /vrātyānām utpattiṃ nāma vṛttiṃ ca /🔽Vaikh / / // ūrdhvajātād adhojātāyāṃ jātoanulomo /
analyzed: vaikh cāturvarṇya saṃkareṇa autpannānām anulomapratiloma antarālavrātyānām utpattim nāma vṛttim ca  ūrdhva jātāt adhas jātāyām jātaḥ anulomaḥ
translated: The origin, names, and occupations of the anuloma, pratiloma, antarāla, and vrātya castes born from the mixture of the four varnas.🔽One born from a higher to a lower caste is an anuloma.

original: Vaikh / / // adhara /utpannād ūrdhvajātāyāṃ jātaḥ pratilomas /
analyzed: vaikh
translated: One born from a lower to a higher caste is a pratiloma.

original: Vaikh / / // tatoanulomād anulomyāṃ jātoantarālaḥ /
analyzed: tatas anulomāt anulomyām jātaḥ antarālaḥ
translated: From that anuloma, one born to an anuloma is an antarāla.

original: Vaikh / / // pratilomāt pratilomyāṃ jāto vrātyo bhavati /
analyzed: pratilomāt pratilomyām jātaḥ vrātyaḥ bhavati
translated: One born from a pratiloma to a pratiloma becomes a vrātya.

original: Vaikh / / // brahmaṇo mukhād udbhūtā brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇyaś ca brahma /ṛṣayaḥ patnyo babhūvus /
analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ mukhāt udbhūtāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ brāhmaṇyaḥ ca brahma ṛṣayaḥ patnyaḥ babhūvuḥ
translated: The Brahmanas and Brahmani women originated from the mouth of Brahma, and became the Brahmana Rishis and their wives.

original: Vaikh / / // teṣāṃ gātra /utpannād brāhmaṇyāṃ a /sagotrāyāṃvidhinā sa /mantrakaṃ gṛhītāyāṃ jāto brāhmaṇaḥ śuddho bhavet /
analyzed: teṣām gātra autpannāt brāhmaṇyām asagotrāyām vidhinā sa mantrakam gṛhītāyām jātaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ śuddhaḥ bhavet
translated: From the body of those Brahmanas, a Brahmana born in the proper manner from a Brahmani who is not of the same Gotra as himself, and who has been taken in marriage with the proper Mantras, shall be pure.

original: Vaikh / / / vidhi /hīnam anya /pūrvāyāṃ golakohartṛkāyāṃ kuṇḍaś ca viprau dvau ninditau syātāṃ /
analyzed: vidhi hīnam anya pūrvāyām kuṇḍaḥ ca viprau dvau ninditau syātām
translated: A Brahmana and a Kshatriya born from a woman who has been married without the proper rites, or from a woman who has been married to another man before, or from a woman who has been married by the Gaval-Dhana form of marriage, shall be censured.

original: Vaikh / / // tasmād adho bāhubhyāmāt kṣatriyāt kṣatriyāyāṃ vidhivatjātaḥ kṣatriyaḥ śuddhas /
analyzed: tasmāt adhas bāhubhyāmāt kṣatriyāt kṣatriyāyām vidhivat jātaḥ kṣatriyaḥ śuddhaḥ
translated: From below the arms, a Kshatriya born in the proper manner from a Kshatriya woman, shall be a pure Kshatriya.

original: Vaikh / / // tayor a /vidhikaṃ gūḍha /utpannoaśuddhobhoja /ākhyo naevaabhiṣecyaḥ
analyzed: tayoḥ avidhikam gūḍha autpannaḥ aśuddhaḥ bhoja ākhyaḥ na eva abhiṣecyaḥ
translated: From those two, one born without the proper rites, or secretly, shall be impure, and be called a Bhoj, and shall not be fit for coronation.

original: paṭṭa /bandho rājñaḥ saināpatyaṃ karoti /
analyzed: paṭṭabandhaḥ rājñaḥ saināpatyam karoti
translated: The tying of the turban by the king is the office of a general.

original: Vaikh / / // śuddha /abhāvea /paṭṭa /bandho nṛṛn pāyāt /
analyzed: śuddha abhāve a paṭṭabandhaḥ pāyāt
translated: In the absence of a pure (Kshatriya), let the one who has the turban protect the people.

original: Vaikh / / // tad /vṛttaṃ rājavat syāt /
analyzed: vaikh tad vṛttam rāja vat syāt
translated: His conduct shall be like that of a king.

original: Vaikh / / / // adhastād ūrubhyāmād vaiśyād vaiśyāyāṃ tathā vaiśyaḥ śuddho /
analyzed: adhastāt vaiśyāt vaiśyāyām tathā vaiśyaḥ śuddhaḥ
translated: From below the thighs, a Vaisya born in the proper manner from a Vaisya woman, shall be a pure Vaisya.

original: Vaikh / / // vidhi /varjaṃ maṇikāroaśuddho maṇi /muktādi /vedhaḥ śaṅkha /valaya /kārī syāt /🔽Vaikh / / // atha padbhyām utpannātśūdrātśudrāyāṃ nyāyenaśūdraḥ śuddhaḥ /
analyzed: vidhi varjam maṇi kāraḥ aśuddhaḥ maṇi muktā ādi vedhaḥ śaṅkha valaya kārī syāt  atha padbhyām utpannāt śūdrāt śudrāyām nyāyena śūdraḥ śuddhaḥ
translated: The son of a Vaishya woman by a Brahmin is a Vaishya.🔽The son of a Shudra woman by a Shudra is a Shudra.🔽The son of a Shudra woman by a Vaishya is a Vaidehaka.

original: Vaikh / / // jārān mālavako ninditaḥśūdroaśvapāloaśva /tṛṇa /hārī ca /🔽Vaikh / / // ity ete cāturvarṇikās /🔽Vaikh / / // teṣām eva saṃskareṇautpannāḥ sarveanuloma /ādyāḥ /
analyzed: jārāt mālavakaḥ ninditaḥ śūdraḥ aśva pālaḥ aśva tṛṇa hārī ca  iti ete cāturvarṇikāḥ  teṣām eva saṃskareṇa autpannāḥ sarve anuloma ādyāḥ
translated: The son of a Shudra woman by a Brahmin is a Vaishya.

original: Vaikh / / // brāhmaṇāt kṣatriya /kanyāyāṃ jātaḥ savarṇoanulomeṣu mukhyo /
analyzed: vaikh brāhmaṇāt kṣatriya kanyāyām jātaḥ savarṇaḥ anulomeṣu mukhyaḥ
translated: The son of a Brahmin woman by a Kshatriya is a Savarna, the best among the Anuloma castes.

original: Vaikh / / / asya vṛttir ātharvaṇaṃkarma /aśva /hasti /ratha /saṃvāhanam ārohaṇaṃ rajñaḥ saināpatyaṃ caāyurveda /kṛtyaṃ /
analyzed: asya vṛttiḥ ātharvaṇam karma aśva hasti ratha saṃvāhanam ārohaṇam saināpatyam ca āyurveda kṛtyam
translated: His profession is Atharvan rites, driving horses, elephants, and chariots, riding for the king, generalship, and medical practice.

original: Vaikh / / // gūḍha /utpannoabhiniṣakta /ākhyo /
analyzed: vaikh gūḍha autpannaḥ abhiniṣakta ākhyaḥ
translated: The son born secretly is called Abhi-nishthita.

original: Vaikh / / // abhiṣiktaś cetnṛpo bhūyād aṣṭāṅgam āyurvedaṃbhūta /tantraṃ vā saṃpaṭet /
analyzed: abhiṣiktaḥ ced nṛpaḥ bhūyāt aṣṭāṅgam āyurvedam bhūtatantram vā saṃpaṭet
translated: If consecrated, he should become a king and master the eight-limbed Ayurveda or the science of elements.

original: Vaikh / / / tad /ukta /ācāro dayā /yuktaḥ satya /vādītad /vidhānena sarvaprāṇi /hitaṃ kuryāt /
analyzed: tad ukta ācāraḥ dayā yuktaḥ satya vādī tad vidhānena sarva prāṇi hitam kuryāt
translated: The Vaikhānasa should follow the conduct described in the scriptures, be full of compassion, truthful, and should do what is beneficial for all beings according to those rules.

original: Vaikh / / // jyotir gaṇana /ādika /adhika /vṛttir vā /🔽Vaikh / / // viprād vaiśyāyām ambaṣṭhaḥkakṣyājīvya /āgneyanartako dhvajaviśrāvī śalya /cikitsī /
analyzed: vaikh jyotiḥ gaṇana ādika adhika vṛttiḥ vā  vaikh viprāt vaiśyāyām ambaṣṭhaḥ kakṣyā jīvya āgneya nartakaḥ dhvaja viśrāvī śalya cikitsī
translated: Or he should have a profession higher than astrology etc.🔽From a Brahmin, a Vaidehaka is born from a Vaishya woman. He should live by making baskets, be a dancer of the fire, announce the flag, and treat wounds.

original: Vaikh / / // jarāt kumbhakāraḥ kulāla /vṛttir naāpito nābherūrdhva /vaptā ca /
analyzed: jarāt kumbhakāraḥ kulāla vṛttiḥ naāpitaḥ nābheḥ ūrdhvavaptā ca
translated: From a Jara, a potter is born. He should have the profession of a potter, be a barber, and shave above the navel.

original: Vaikh / / // kṣatriyād vaiśyāyāṃ madguḥ śreṣṭhitvaṃ prāpto mahānarma /ākhyaś ca vaiśya /vṛttiḥ kṣātram karma naācarati /
analyzed: kṣatriyāt vaiśyāyām madguḥ śreṣṭhi tvam prāptaḥ mahānarma ākhyaḥ ca vaiśya vṛttiḥ kṣātram karma na ācarati
translated: From a Kshatriya, a Madgu is born from a Vaishya woman. He attains superiority and is called a great entertainer. He has the profession of a Vaishya and does not perform Kshatriya duties.

original: Vaikh / / // gūḍhād āśvikoaśva /kraya /vikrayī syāt /
analyzed: vaikh gūḍhāt āśvikaḥ aśva kraya vikrayī syāt
translated: From a Guhyaka, an Ashvika is born. He should deal in buying and selling horses.

original: Vaikh / / // viprātśūdrāyāṃ pāraśavo bhadrakālī /pūjana /citrakarma /aṅgavidyā /tūryaghoṣaṇa /mardana /vṛttir /
analyzed: viprāt śūdrāyām pāraśavaḥ bhadrakālī pūjana citrakarma aṅga vidyā tūrya ghoṣaṇa mardana vṛttiḥ
translated: From a Brahmin, a Parashara is born from a Shudra woman. He should have the profession of worshipping Bhadrakali, painting, learning the arts, playing musical instruments, and beating drums.

original: Vaikh / / // jāra /utpanno niṣādo vyāḍādi /mṛgahiṃsā /kārī /
translated: A Nishada is born from a paramour. He should harm animals such as tigers.

original: Vaikh / / // rājanyataḥ śūdrāyām ugraḥ sudaṇḍya /daṇḍana /kṛtyo /
analyzed: rājanyataḥ śūdrāyām ugraḥ su daṇḍya daṇḍana kṛtyo
translated: From a Kshatriya, an Ugra is born from a Shudra woman. He should punish those who deserve severe punishment.

original: Vaikh / / // jārātśūlikaḥ śūlārohaṇādi /yātanā /kṛtyo /🔽Vaikh / / // vaiśyataḥ śūdrāyāṃ cūcukaḥ kramukata /ambūla /śarkarādi /kraya /vikrayī /
analyzed: vaikh  vaikh vaiśyataḥ śūdrāyām cūcukaḥ
translated: The son of a Vaishya by a Shudra woman, born in the reverse order, is a Chuchuka, who deals in betel nuts, betel leaves, sugar, etc.🔽The son of a Vaishya by a Vaishya woman, born in the reverse order, is a Katkari, who makes baskets.

original: Vaikh / / // gūḍhāt kaṭakāraḥ kaṭakārī caiti /🔽Vaikh / / // tatoanulomād anulomāyāṃ jātaś caanulomaḥpitur mātur vā jātaṃ vṛttiṃ bhajeta /
analyzed: vaikh gūḍhāt kaṭakāraḥ kaṭakārī ca eti  tatas anulomāt anulomāyām jātaḥ ca anulomaḥ pituḥ mātuḥ vā jātam vṛttim bhajeta

translated: He should remove the impurities elsewhere and throw them outside.🔽A Vaikhānasa should live outside the village, far away, with those of his own kind.

analyzed: viśet ced rājñā vadhyaḥ
translated: If he enters, he should be killed by the king.

original: Vaikh / / // anyathā bhrūṇahatyām avāpnoty /
analyzed: anyathā bhrūṇahatyām avāpnoti
translated: Otherwise, he incurs the sin of killing a fetus.

original: Vaikh / / // antarāl /vratyāś ca /
analyzed: vaikh antarālvratyāḥ ca
translated: There are also intermediate Vratyas.

original: Vaikh / / // cūcukād viprāyāṃ takṣakoaspṛśyojhallarī /hasto dārukāraḥ suvarṇakāroayaskāraḥ kāṃsyakāro vā /

translated: From a Chuchuka, a Takshaka untouchable, a lute player, a carpenter, a goldsmith, an ironsmith, or a brass worker, in a Brahmin woman.

original: Vaikh / / // kṣatriyāyāṃ matsya /bandhur matsyabandhī /🔽Vaikh / / /vaiśyāyāṃ sāmudraḥ samudrapaṇya /jīvīmatsya /ghātī ca syāt /
analyzed: vaikh kṣatriyāyām matsyabandhuḥ matsyabandhī  vaikh sāmudraḥ samudra paṇya jīvī matsya ghātī ca syāt
translated: From a Kshatriya woman, a fish-binder, a fisherman.🔽From a Vaishya woman, a sailor, one who makes a living from sea trade and kills fish.

original: Vaikh / / // ambaṣṭhād viprāyāṃ nāvikaḥsamudrapaṇya /matsya /jīvī samudra /laṅghanāṃ nāvaṃ plāvayati /
analyzed: ambaṣṭhāt viprāyām nāvikaḥ samudra paṇya matsya jīvī samudra laṅghanām nāvam plāvayati
translated: From an Ambashtha, a boatman who sails a boat across the ocean, makes a living from sea trade and fish, in a Brahmin woman.

original: Vaikh / / // kṣatriyāyām adhonāpito nābher adho roma /vaptā /
analyzed: vaikh kṣatriyāyām adhonāpitaḥ nābheḥ adhas roma vaptā
translated: From a Kshatriya woman, an under-shaver, one who shaves below the navel.

original: Vaikh / / // madgor viprāyāṃ veṇuko veṇu /vīṇā /vādī /
analyzed: madgoḥ viprāyām veṇukaḥ veṇu vīṇā vādī
translated: From a Madgu, a flute player, one who plays the flute and the veena, in a Brahmin woman.

original: Vaikh / / // kṣatriyāyāṃ karmakaraḥ karmakārī /
analyzed: vaikh kṣatriyāyām karmakaraḥ karma kārī
translated: A Karmara from a Kshatriya woman is a laborer.

original: Vaikh / / // vaidehakād viprāyāṃ carmakāraś carma /jīvī /
analyzed: vaikh vaidehakāt viprāyām carmakāraḥ carma jīvī
translated: A Carmaka from a Vaidehaka and a Brahmin woman is a leather worker, who makes a living from leather.

original: Vaikh / / // nṛpāyāṃ sūcikaḥ sūcī /vedhana /kṛtyavān /
analyzed: nṛpāyām sūcikaḥ sūcī vedhana kṛtyavān
translated: A Sucika from a Nripa woman is skilled in sewing with a needle.

original: Vaikh / / // āyogavād viprāyāṃ tāmras tāmra /jīvī /
analyzed: āyogavāt viprāyām tāmraḥ tāmra jīvī
translated: A Tamra from an Ayogava and a Brahmin woman is a copper worker, who makes a living from copper.

original: Vaikh / / // nṛpāyāṃ khanakaḥ khanana /jīvī /
analyzed: nṛpāyām khanakaḥ khanana jīvī
translated: A Khanaka from a Nripa woman is a digger, who makes a living from digging.

original: Vaikh / / / khananān nṛpāyām udbandhakaḥ śūdra /aspṛśyo vastra /nirṇejakaḥ /
analyzed: khananāt udbandhakaḥ śūdra aspṛśyaḥ vastra nirṇejakaḥ
translated: An Udbandhaka from a Khanana and a Nripa woman is an outcaste, who cleans clothes for Shudras.

original: Vaikh / / // pulkasād viprāyāṃ rajako vastrāṇāṃrajo /nirṇejakaś /
analyzed: pulkasāt viprāyām rajakaḥ vastrāṇām rajaḥ nirṇejakaḥ
translated: A Rajaka from a Pulkasa and a Brahmin woman is a washerman, who cleans the dirt from clothes.

original: Vaikh / / / // caṇḍālād viprāyāṃ śvapacaḥ caṇḍālavaccihna /yukto nitya /nindyaḥ sarvakarma /bahiṣkāryo nagaryādau mala /apohakaḥ śmaśāne
analyzed: caṇḍālāt viprāyām śvapacaḥ caṇḍāla vat cihna yuktaḥ nitya nindyaḥ sarva karma bahiṣkāryaḥ nagarī ādau mala apohakaḥ śmaśāne
translated: A Shvapacha from a Chandala and a Brahmin woman is a scavenger, marked like a Chandala, always censured, excluded from all rites, and in a town etc. he removes filth in a cremation ground.

original: heyapātra /grāhī pretam abandhukaṃ visṛjeta /
analyzed: heya pātra grāhī pretam abandhukam visṛjeta
translated: He should offer a funeral oblation to a dead person who has no relatives.

original: Vaikh / / // vadhyān hatvā tad /vastrādi /grāhīparādhīna /āhāro bhinnapātra /bhojī śvamāṃsa /bhakṣī carma /vāra /vāṇa /vāṇijya /kārī syāt /
analyzed: vadhyān hatvā tad vastra ādi grāhī para adhīna āhāraḥ bhinna pātra bhojī śva māṃsa bhakṣī carma vāra vāṇa vāṇijya kārī syāt
translated: Having killed those who deserve to be killed, he should take their clothes etc., eat from a broken vessel, eat dog meat, and engage in the trade of leather, wool, and arrows, and subsist on food obtained from others.

original: Vaikh / / // tasmān nikṛṣṭe sute samutpanne patito naṣṭoghorān narakān vrajati /
analyzed: tasmāt nikṛṣṭe sute samutpanne patitaḥ naṣṭaḥ ghorān narakān vrajati
translated: Therefore, when a low-quality son is born, the father becomes fallen and goes to terrible hells.

original: Vaikh / / // sat /putro narakebhyas trāyakaḥ pitṛṛnpāvayitvā/
analyzed: sat putraḥ narakebhyaḥ trāyakaḥ pitṛṛn pāvayitvā
translated: The good son is the savior from hells, purifying the ancestors.

original: śubhāṃl lokān nayati /
analyzed: śubhān lokān nayati
translated: He leads them to auspicious worlds.

original: Vaikh / / // tasmād brāhmaṇādyāḥ savarṇāyāṃ vidhivat putram utpādayeyur
analyzed: tasmāt brāhmaṇa ādyāḥ savarṇāyām vidhivat putram utpādayeyuḥ
translated: Therefore, Brahmins and others should produce a son according to the rules from a woman of the same class.

original: iti vikhanāḥ / End of the text /
analyzed: iti vikhanāḥ end of the text
translated: Thus says Vyāsa. End of the text.
